origination.corpname: University of Michigan. Medical School Sesquicentennial Office.

did.unittitle: Medical School Sesquicentennial Office (University of Michigan) records 1997-2000
did.abstract: Office established to plan and coordinate events, exhibits, and publicity for the University of Michigan Medical School sesquicentennial. Records include committee minutes, event schedules and planning material, press releases, clippings, articles, publicity, script and production files for sesquicentennial video, and student life photographs. Also includes videotape and audio tape of media coverage of events and lapel pins and merchandise created for the sesquicentennial.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

did.physloc: Portions located in offsite storage; prior notification required for access.

acqinfo.p: The record group was transferred by the University of Michigan Medical School Sesquicentennial Office (Donor no. 647) in January 2001.

accruals.p: No further additions to the records are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Medical School Sesquicentennial Office (University of Michigan) records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The University of Michigan Medical School was founded in 1848 and graduated its first class in 1850. The school celebrated its centennial in 1950, so in March 1997, the dean of the Medical School, Lorris Betz, began planning a sesquicentennial celebration for the Medical School for the year 2000. An administrative committee created a plan for the celebration and created an office to coordinate the celebration. The plan, approved in March 1998 included the publication of a book and video, exhibits and displays for the University of Michigan community and the Medical Center, departmental events, a symposium, regional meetings, and a variety of ceremonies and celebrations, beginning with a convocation ceremony in October 1999, through a gala final celebration in October 2000. Allen S. Lichter continued the plans when he became dean in December, 1998.

The Sesquicentennial office operated from 1998 until the end of 2000, and oversaw the implementation of the sesquicentennial plan and publicity. Staff of the sesquicentennial office included head coordinator Kate Schuch, Linda Diebold, Deborah Grifka and consultant Jean Horrigan. A sesquicentennial committee was formed of doctors from each of the departments, representatives from the Medical School dean's office, the Medical Center Alumni and Development Office, the Historical Center for the Health Sciences, and the sesquicentennial staff, chaired by Robert Bartlett. The committee met from 1998 through 2000 to coordinate the sesquicentennial celebrations.

The committee hired a public relations firm, Franco Public Relations, to coordinate a national publicity campaign for print, radio and television. Recognition was received from a number of sources. The Medical School Sesquicentennial was noted in the United States Congressional Record, was the subject of a Journal of the American Medical Association issue, as well as numerous articles published in local and national newspapers and magazines. Segments about the sesquicentennial were aired on the NBC Today Show and Detroit Radio WJR-AM station's morning show in February 2000. A logo design for the sesquicentennial was created and used for stationery, stickers, invitations, brochures, and a variety of merchandise.

A number of exhibits and displays were created for the sesquicentennial. A time line of accomplishments was created as a poster and displayed on the sesquicentennial web site. Alumni were asked for memories, and their letters created a "Memory Lane" display, both within the medical center and on the web site. The Medical Center also had a variety of displays within the buildings, including class photograph displays, alumni hall of honor, a display of an iron lung machine, a display of antique surgeons' tools and a turn-of-the-century doctor's office. The University Art Museum also held an exhibition titled Seeing is Healing, The Visual Arts of Medicine. Historical Markers were designed and placed around the campus where the original medical buildings once stood.

A number of large events were planned for the sesquicentennial year. The kickoff event, a convocation in October 1999, was held at the same time as an all-alumni reunion. The convocation brought together distinguished alumni speakers and paid tribute to the Medical School's history. A symposium, speakers, and small events celebrated the sesquicentennial until the finale week which included a Medical Center birthday party luncheon, and a gala dinner to close the year's events.

In addition, a video was created to publicize the history of the Medical School with narration by University of Michigan alumnus Mike Wallace. A book on the school Not Just Any Medical School by Horace Davenport was revised and published for the sesquicentennial. The sesquicentennial office also published Know Thy Place, a compendium of biographies of notable Medical School alumni.

The Sesquicentennial committee involved the students by creating a "day in the life of a medical school student" display. The student were given 33 disposable cameras and told to photograph student life. The sesquicentennial brought together the whole of the Medical School, alumni, faculty, staff, and students, to celebrate its heritage.

For more information on the Medical School, please see the Medical School web site: http://www.med.umich.edu/medschool. For more archival information please see the University of Michigan Medical School finding aid at the Bentley Library.

scopecontent.p: The records consist of material created and compiled by the staff of the Medical School Sesquicentennial Office. The records include a variety of information about the planning and production of special events, and publications and publicity for the 150-year anniversary of the Medical School.
The collection is divided into eight series: Sesquicentennial Committee Materials, Publicity, Exhibits and Displays, Events, Audio-Visual, Publications, and Artifacts.

scopecontent.p: The records of the Sesquicentennial Committee contain a planning guide, a calendar of events, meeting minutes, correspondence and information about department involvement in the celebration.

did.unittitle: Committee Minutes, (including overall plan and chronology of major contributions list) December 1997-1999
Committee Correspondence, including committee member list and meeting planning information May 1997-October 1998
Planning for Communications and Publicity circa 1998
Jean Horrigan, Event Planning Evaluation Report April 1999

scopecontent.p: Publicity materials consist of reports from the Public Relations firm, informational media kits, and numerous clippings from publications and articles about the Medical School Sesquicentennial from a variety of journals, newsletters and newspapers, and planning materials for multiple exhibits and displays on campus.

did.unittitle: University Medical Center Media Release Package 2000
Publicity Firm Proposals, Franco Public Relations Firm Meetings and Memos August 1998-November 1999
Franco Public Relations Report on Newspaper Coverage March 2000-July 2000
Franco Public Relations Correspondence, Monthly Reports, and Clippings December 1998-February 2000
Sesquicentennial Media Kit, includes committee list, dean list and speaker biographies 1999
Ann Arbor News clippings, and correspondence with Dave Whalberg, Ann Arbor News, June 1998-September 1999
Design of Sesquicentennial Logo and Stationery 1999

scopecontent.p: The Sesquicentennial included several exhibits and displays in the Medical Center, on the university campus and at the University of Michigan Art Museum. The records include information about the development, planning, research, location and presentation of the exhibits and displays.

did.unittitle: Time Line and Alumni Memory Project
Department Time Line Posters from Ophthalmology and Physiology circa 1999 (located in oversize folder)
Memory Lane Project from Alumni Letters 1998-1999
Medical School Deans Portraits: Proposal for Restoration and Conservation 1997
Art Museum Exhibit Proposal: Seeing is Healing, The Visual Arts of Medicine, 1998
Seeing is Healing, The Visual Arts of Medicine Exhibit Opening and Unveiling of New Medical School Deans Portraits, August 1999-October 2000
Research about the Possible Reconstruction of the Old Main Hospital Arch at the Medical School 1998
Plans for Historical Building Plaques for Early Medical Building Sites 1999
Exhibits for Display Within the Medical Center
Exhibits and Displays Planned for Medical Center Buildings 1998-2000
Proposals for Turn-of-the-century Doctor's Office Display 1999
Class Photograph Preservation and Repair, for Display in Medical Science I Building (includes display layout) 1999
Proposal for Medical Science II Building Mural circa 1999 (located in oversize folder)
Medical Center Alumni Society Hall of Honor Display and Brochure 1998-1999

scopecontent.p: The Medical School community planned a number of events for the Sesquicentennial year, including an opening convocation, an all-alumni reunion, a symposium, various lectures throughout the year, a Medical Center birthday luncheon for the medical school and medical center staff and a final gala celebration to end the sesquicentennial year. The materials contain planning, staffing, coordination and location information on most Sesquicentennial events

did.unittitle: All Alumni Reunion Plan for the Convocation Weekend 1999
"Will Professionalism be a Casualty of Modern Medicine?" Symposium Preparation and Brochure 1999-2000
Medical School Birthday Party Events, including Pfizer Donation of Breakfast for Medical Offices 2000
Sesquicentennial Gala, Final Event Planning and Invitation 1999-2000
Journal of the American Medical Association (Volume 283 Number 7), February 2000
Journal of the American Medical Association Edition Publicity Poster, 1999 (located in oversize folder)
Drafts of Articles for Journal of the American Medical Association University of Michigan Sesquicentennial Issue, circa 1999

Michigan Medicine, Michigan State Medical Society Magazine, Article on Medical School Dean Allen S. Lichter, August-September 2000
Not Just Any Medical School printing and Distribution, 1998-1999
Celebrating 150 Years of Scholarship and Service, University of Michigan Medical School, Video Contract agreement, award applications 1998
Video Research and Box Cover Design 1997-1999

scopecontent.p: The audio-video records contain the Sesquicentennial video that was written and produced about the history of the Medical School, tapes of publicity spots on NBC's Today show, a Detroit Radio Morning show, and a educational CD-ROM from one of the Sesquicentennial committee members. The records include numerous photographs and negatives from disposable cameras given to Medical school students to document daily student life. Artifacts created with the Sesquicentennial logo are included in the record group.
